title: How to Make Safe Sun Tea

steps.headline: Wash the jar.
steps.description: Thoroughly wash out a clear tea jar with antibacterial soap. Then fill with boiling hot water to help kill any bacteria left after using the soap.

steps.headline: Add water.
steps.description: Proceed to fill the container with four cups of cold water and add in the tea of choice. Be sure to only make enough tea that will, for certain, be consumed within a few hours.

steps.headline: Place the container in direct sunlight for at least two hours.
When the time is up, go outside and remove the tea bags, or strain out the leaves.
Enjoy it.
steps.description: It is recommended that you drink immediately or store in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Know when not to consume it.
steps.description: If the drink has a thick or syrupy appearance, do not drink it as it may be contaminated with a bacteria that could make you sick.

steps.headline: Have an indepth read about this tea.
steps.description:
Here is what The Centers for Disease Control and the National Tea Association recommends when making sun tea:
Brew tea bags at 195 °F (91 °C) for three to five minutes. Brew only enough tea that can be consumed within a few hours. Never maintain brewed tea for more than eight hours at room temperature. Discard any unused tea after eight hours.

steps.headline: Wash, rinse, and sanitize tea-making equipment regularly.
Brew the tea in the refrigerator overnight instead of outdoors.
By following these simple suggestions you can minimize your risk.
steps.description: Be wise and use your own judgment.

text:
Wash the jar. Thoroughly wash out a clear tea jar with antibacterial soap. Then fill with boiling hot water to help kill any bacteria left after using the soap. Add water. Proceed to fill the container with four cups of cold water and add in the tea of choice. Be sure to only make enough tea that will, for certain, be consumed within a few hours. Place the container in direct sunlight for at least two hours.  When the time is up, go outside and remove the tea bags, or strain out the leaves.  Enjoy it. It is recommended that you drink immediately or store in the refrigerator. Know when not to consume it. If the drink has a thick or syrupy appearance, do not drink it as it may be contaminated with a bacteria that could make you sick. Have an indepth read about this tea. Here is what The Centers for Disease Control and the National Tea Association recommends when making sun tea:
Brew tea bags at 195 °F (91 °C) for three to five minutes. Brew only enough tea that can be consumed within a few hours. Never maintain brewed tea for more than eight hours at room temperature. Discard any unused tea after eight hours. Wash, rinse, and sanitize tea-making equipment regularly.  Brew the tea in the refrigerator overnight instead of outdoors.  By following these simple suggestions you can minimize your risk. Be wise and use your own judgment.
